channel.title: Comments on: Has FireFox lost its Mojo, are FireFox user jumping ship to Chrome?
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Less Than Dot - Blog - Less Than Dot is two years old, here are some stats
item.dc:creator: Less Than Dot - Blog - Less Than Dot is two years old, here are some stats
item.description: […] As you can see Internet Explorer is the number one browser, last year it was FireFox. Chrome is still number 3 but it doubled its share. FireFox is the big loser, I wrote about that already here: Has FireFox lost its Mojo, are FireFox user jumping ship to Chrome? […]
item.content:encoded: […] As you can see Internet Explorer is the number one browser, last year it was FireFox. Chrome is still number 3 but it doubled its share. FireFox is the big loser, I wrote about that already here: Has FireFox lost its Mojo, are FireFox user jumping ship to Chrome? […]

item.title: By: Em
item.dc:creator: Em
item.description: I'm with Chrome too. There's one thing about it thought that I don't get. That's the font it uses for the address bar. It's just hard to read.
item.content:encoded: I’m with Chrome too. There’s one thing about it thought that I don’t get. That’s the font it uses for the address bar. It’s just hard to read.

item.title: By: Kent
item.dc:creator: Kent
item.content:encoded:
I like Chrome, but unfortunately AdBlock+ doesn’t work as well under Chrome as it does under Firefox. I just _knew_ Google wouldn’t help us hide its cash cow.

I use Chrome at work, where our proxy server makes up for AdBlock’s misses.

item.title: By: Schoenobates
item.dc:creator: Schoenobates
item.content:encoded:
I dumped FF in favour of Chrome as I found FF to be such a hog (both on win and lin). Chrome is much better mainly by the fact that each tab is effectively it’s own isolated process, meaning one bad plugin generally can’t cripple the whole browser (I say that, but it happened to me just yesterday, but definitely not as much as I’ve seen in FF)

£0.02

item.title: By: traingamer
item.dc:creator: traingamer
item.description: We're locked into IE at work (IE6 at the present time - IE8 by year end). I much prefer FireFox at home. Chrome does have a smaller footprint, but it also doesn't do as much for me.
item.content:encoded: We’re locked into IE at work (IE6 at the present time – IE8 by year end). I much prefer FireFox at home. Chrome does have a smaller footprint, but it also doesn’t do as much for me.

item.title: By: Ofc
item.dc:creator: Ofc
item.content:encoded:
Firefox is huge bloat. XPCOM, XUL and other js over use.
JS function calls from C++. Thats just what browser needs.
Layer of abstraction on layer of abstraction. <333

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.content:encoded:
No, the script blocking is built into the browser. But it’s not fine-grained enough. Once you allow a certain domain, any request generated from a page on that domain is allowed (as opposed to the NoScript approach where you need to allow each SOURCE domain).

Host files are nice, but I still prefer to specify what I trust instead of what I don’t.

item.title: By: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Baes (chrissie1)
item.description: I like firefox still because chrome does not have everything I have on FF. And I'm old and change doesn't come easy.
item.content:encoded: I like firefox still because chrome does not have everything I have on FF. And I’m old and change doesn’t come easy.

item.title: By: SQLDenis
item.dc:creator: SQLDenis
item.content:encoded:
>>This doesn’t make up for its’ crippled script-blocking which seems to be designed more for maximizing google’s ad revenue than actually protecting users

Isn’t that just a 3rd party extension or are you now allowed to create a noscript extension on Chrome?

Anyway I also use this host file to block certain bad sites http://www.mvps.org/winhelp2002/hosts.htm

item.title: By: Alex Ullrich
item.dc:creator: Alex Ullrich
item.content:encoded:
I like Chrome because its’ fast and should push firefox to improve performance.

This doesn’t make up for its’ crippled script-blocking which seems to be designed more for maximizing google’s ad revenue than actually protecting users. Until that is corrected, I can’t use it seriously or recommend it to anyone else.
